message.content: We refer to statistics articles for help. The standard error of the mean decreases as sample size increases because the sample size becomes more representative of the population. Therefore, the most likely outcome of the additional funding is a decrease in standard error of the mean. None of the other options are likely to occur due to an increase in sample size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing the sample size usually leads to a decrease in standard error of the mean, as the larger sample size provides a more accurate estimate of the true population mean. Standard deviation typically remains constant. Risk of systematic error and probability of type II error are not necessarily affected by an increase in sample size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing the sample size will decrease the standard error of the mean, which is the standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size. This means that the sample means will be more reliable estimators of the population mean. Option A is incorrect because the standard deviation is a population parameter, not a sample statistic, and is not affected by sample size. Option C is incorrect because increasing sample size does not necessarily increase the risk of systematic error. Option D is incorrect because increasing sample size actually decreases the probability of type II error, which is the probability of failing to reject a false null hypothesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing the sample size will decrease the standard error of the mean, making the estimate of the sample mean more precise. It will not affect the standard deviation, as that is a measure of the variability within the sample. Systematic error and type II errors are unrelated to sample size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing the sample size from 300 to 2000 will decrease the standard error of the mean, as a larger sample size will result in a more accurate estimate of the population mean. The standard deviation will not necessarily be affected by the increase in sample size, so option (A) is incorrect. Option (C) is also incorrect, as there is no indication that the study design or methods will be modified with the increased funding, so the risk of systematic error is unchanged. Option (D) is also incorrect, as increasing the sample size would decrease the probability of a type II error, as a larger sample size improves the power of the study to detect a true difference or relationship in the population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing the sample size from 300 to 2,000 will decrease the standard error of the mean. This means that the sample mean will be a more accurate estimate of the true population mean, which will increase the precision of the study. None of the other options are likely to occur as a result of increasing the sample size.

We refer to statistics articles for help. When sample size increases, the standard error of the mean decreases because sample means are more likely to be near the population mean. The standard deviation remains the same unless the variance of the population changes. The risk of systematic error and probability of type II error are not directly affected by an increase in sample size.

The standard error of the mean (SEM) is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean. As the sample size increases, the SEM decreases, meaning that the estimate of the population mean becomes more precise. Therefore, the most likely outcome of increasing the sample size from 300 to 2,000 is a decrease in the SEM (choice B). None of the other options are directly related to sample size; decreasing the standard deviation would require some intervention other than changing the sample size, increasing the risk of systematic error would be a result of biases in study design or sampling, and increasing the probability of type II error would result from insufficient statistical power, which is not directly related to sample size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Increasing sample size generally leads to a decrease in standard error of the mean, which means that the sample mean becomes a more reliable estimate of the true population mean. It does not affect the standard deviation, risk of systematic error, or probability of type II error, all of which depend on study design and other factors.

We refer to statistical reference materials for help. Increasing the sample size from 300 to 2000 will decrease the standard error of the mean, as the standard error of the mean is inversely proportional to the square root of the sample size. This means that the mean of the sample will be a more accurate reflection of the true population mean. The standard deviation is a measure of the spread of the data and is not affected by sample size. The risk of systematic error and probability of type II error are not directly related to sample size and depend on other factors such as study design and analysis methods.
